results.title: A Man of the world: H.H. the Aga Khan
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Anthony de Lotbinière and Georges Robin
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
The Aga Khan is the creator of one of the world’s most dramatic and imaginative development schemes - a planned riviera along 35 miles of Sardinia’s Costa Smeralda. He is also the spiritual leader of more than 12 million Ismaili-Muslims scattered around the world, and a wealthy Parisian, racehourse owner, and Olympic skier. Shows the Aga Khan in a variety of activities. He comments personally, analysing himself and his different faces with the same detached lucidity he brings to all his undertakings.

results.title: A Man of the wilderness
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Anthony de Lotbinière and Georges Robin
results.brief_description: In the southern part of France there is a part which is stark because of the lack of water, and almost impossible to live off. But one man, Phillippe Lamour bought a farm in the area. During the war he cultivated his vines and made a success of it. Other Langadock farmers came to look upon him as a leader. After the end of the war he lobbied government to provide funds for an irrigation project. After 12 years of frustration the project finally started - irrigation enabled farmers to produce extra goods, their standard of living increased by 40%-50%. Lamour’s vision of agriculture, industry and tourism is now being realised.

results.title: A Man for all seasons [a discussion]
results.creator_credit: Country Education Project and Daryl Wayland
results.brief_description: Bolt’s play, set in Tudor England in the 16th century, concentrates on the battle for Tomas More’s conscience and his loyalty. Dennis O’Hearn of Melbourne University discusses the character of More, his relationships with other characters and his historical background to the play.

results.title: A Man for all seasons
results.brief_description: Robert Bolt’s literate and penetrating treatment of the conflict waged between Sir Thomas More and King Henry VIII makes a smooth transition to the screen. Zinnemann has mounted a film with an eye for characterisation rather than spectacle and the result is a superior drama. Stars Paul Scofield, Robert Shaw, Wendy Hiller, Orson Welles, Susannah York and Vanessa Redgrave. Rated: G

results.title: A Man escaped = Un Condamne a mort e'est echappe = Le Vent souffle ou il vent
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional, Alain Poire, Jean Thuillier and Robert Bresson
results.brief_description: Based on the true life account of Resistance fighter Andre Devigny, who was imprisoned and condemned to death by the Nazis, “A Man Escaped” is one of cinema’s truly poetic films, a study in both the psychology of imprisonment and loss of liberty, as well as a tense and involving study of how a man plotted his escape from one of the most heavily guarded prisons in World War II. As played by Francois Letterier, the condemned man’s initial fear and anger give way to a resolve and determination to defy his fascist captors. But, as his plans are disturbed on the eve of his execution, he achieves a transcendence by accepting the inevitability of fate, the need to trust another human being, and finally having the knowledge that by not surrendering his will - whatever the outcome of his escape - he has truly liberated himself from the enemy. Winner of the Best Director Award a Cannes in 1957, stunningly photographed by L. H. Burel, and featuring an evocative use of Mozart’s Mass in C Minor, this is universally acknowledged as one of Bresson’s supreme works. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: A Man called Sledge
results.creator_credit: De Laurentiis Entertainment Group, Dino De Laurentiis and Vic Morrow
results.brief_description: Outlaw Luther Sledge (James Garner) sets out with his bandit gang to steal a half million dollar consignment of gold bullion which is shipped each week through a small western town. His scheme involves stealing the gold from within a local prison where it is held overnight. This daring escapade leads to a sequence of betrayals and a violent trail of vengeance across the Mexican border. This is a dramatic and fast-moving western which casts James Garner in the unusual role of villain, the supporting cast includes Dennis Weaver, Claude Akins and John Marley.

results.title: A Man called Edison
results.creator_credit: Spectra Pictures and Dennis R. Atkinson
results.brief_description: Presents Thomas Edison’s contributions to the motion picture industry through his early kinetoscope films. Provides a vivid panorama of early moviemaking. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: A Man and his dog
results.creator_credit: Supreme Sound Studios and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: An account of the training of Kelpie dogs in the handling of sheep on an Australian sheep station. Explains the possible origin of the breed; shows the special training a dog receives from the time he is a small pup until he can muster and control a mob of a thousand or more sheep; shows the confidence of the dog and the bond of friendship which springs up between the animals and their masters.
